We need to load the following R libraries:
















::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)
library(dplyr)
```
:::
















Create two plots:
















::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p1 <- ggplot(iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Sepal Length vs Sepal Width") +
  theme_minimal()

p2 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Weight vs MPG") +
  theme_minimal()
```
:::
















Now we can arrange the two plots side by side using the `patchwork` package:
















::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p1 + p2
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Side by side plots using patchwork](index_files/figure-html/fig-side-side-plot-1.png){#fig-side-side-plot width=768}
:::
:::
















You can also customize the layout further, for example by adding a common title or adjusting the spacing:
















::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
(p1 + p2) +
  plot_layout(ncol = 2) +
  plot_annotation(title = "Side by Side Plots in ggplot2") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Common title](index_files/figure-html/fig-side-side-plot-1-1.png){#fig-side-side-plot-1 width=768}
:::
:::
















You can also position the plots one below the other:
















::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p1 / p2
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Top and bottom plots using patchwork](index_files/figure-html/fig-top-bottom-plot-1.png){#fig-top-bottom-plot width=384}
:::
:::
